HOPKINS AT THE MEET

Price Second in Intercollegiate Oratorical Contest Last Friday Night
in McCoy Hall.

Plans May Be Changed at Homewood.
More Space Will Probably Be
Given to Athletics.

Records Broken in Three Events—Hopkin, Wins Few Points—Freddie
Lee in the Limelight.

Impressive exercises, commemorating the founding of the Johns
Hopkins University, will be held on
Thursday, in McCoy Hall. The
Principal address will be by Dr. S.
Weir Mitchell, of Philadelphia, who
will be presented with the degree of
doctor of laws. President Remsen
Will make some of his customary
announcements," and it is expected
that he will have something interesting to say concerning the removal
to Homewood, the plans for the

DR. S. WEIR

MITCHELL.

buildings,
and the progress of the
ndowment • and Extension Fund.
.After the exercises, the alumni
Will hold a brief meeting. At night,
there will be a banquet, and the results announced.

BALTIMORE, MD., FEB. 19, 1912
Time to Act.

Barely three months and a half
remain before the present seniors
will be graduated. But this is
plenty of time.for plans to be made
for a more adequate commence- •
ment, with a class day, or night, a
baccalaureate sermon, a banquet, a
trip down the bay, the presentation
of a play, or any activity which
would help keep memorable the last
week which many of us will spend
at the Johns Hopkins University.
Tiii Xi.:\vs-LETTER believes that
it is. a crying shame that more
sentiment is not attached by the
students to the graduation exercises, but when any complaint is
made, that perennial sins-of-omission excuse is heard: "Wait until
We get to Homewood." We have
been waiting though for several
years,- and we will have to wait
Several more. • The time to act is
now.
And SO THE NMS-LETTER respectfully suggests to President
Lee, of the senior class, that he appoint at once a committee to make
plans for some student celebrations
.during commencement week. We
believe that there is a widespread
sentiment favoring this, and if a
committee made some good sugkestions, the favorable sentiment
would speedily crystallize into support.

annual two-mile rely race between
Pennsylvania and Carlisle. The
score of victories was even until
Saturday night, when Pennsylvania
beat the Indians for the second'
time in two years. Pennsylvania
was never in danger of losing from
the crack of the pistol to the tape.
The meet was conceded to be the
best ever held in Baltimore.
From a standpoint of records
broken, one world's record and two
local records, from a standpoint of
the number of stars the meet attracted and their respective localities, and also from a standpoint of
interest shown by attendance, Hopkins can feel sure that her efforts
to promote track athletics have
been of avail.

The authorities request the punctual attendance of all students, members of the faculty and trustees.
The following order will be preserved:
The trustees, the faculty, and the
official guests are invited to assemble
at 10.30 o'clock in Levering Hall,
corner of Eutaw street and Druid
Hill avenue.
The alumni are invited to assemble at 10.30 in the second story
of McCoy Hall (north side).
The students are requested to
meet at 10.20 in the places designated below, and will proceed, under
the direction of their marshals, to
the seats reserved for them:
Graduate students in the arts and
sciences, in Room io, McCoy Hall.
Students of medicine, in Room
12, McCoy Hall.
Undergraduate students, in Room
McCoy Hall.
The procession will enter the assembly room at 10.45.
A part of the assembly room will
be reserved until 10.45 for the families of the trustees and faculty, who
will be admitted by special cards.
After the procession has entered,
the remaining seats will be open to
the public without tickets.

location of the dormitories has been
asked for for a baseball field, and
if the request is granted, the dormitories will have to be shifted. These
problems were put up to the new
Advisory Board, and they came together with President Remsen and
Mr. R. Brent Keyser last Thursday
night to confer. It is probable that
a complete shift will be made in the
original plans. This will no doubt
take some time and cause a delay
in actual building.
It is expected that the University
will be formally told of the changes
at the commemoration day exercises
next Thursday. It has been the
custom for the last few years to report the progress on the Homewood
plans on this occasion, and judging
from the precedent, some part of
the program will be devoted to the
Homewood development. Nd actual work has been done on the tract
in the past year, except the erection of some new buildings in the
botanical gardens, and some grading. Between $6o,000 and $7o,00o
has been spent so far, excluding the
salaries of the workmen.
Very few people realize the size
of the Wyman tract on which the
new University is to stand. Professor Mathews, of the geological
department, who is one of the most
enthusiastic workers on the Homewood Board, has compared the size
of the Homewood grounds with the
size of the business section of the
city. He placed a map of the tract
on a map of the city, both of which
were on the same scale, placing the
southernmost point of the tract
on 'Baltimore and Liberty streets.
Charles street will fall on Charles
street. With the maps so placed,
the north end of Homewood will
fall On the Richmond Market Armory. The tract extends in breadth
from Charles street to about as far
as Eutaw. The library to be built
according to the new plans could
hardly be placed on the present site
of the University. The new laboratories will cover about three blocks.
The dormitories will occupy about
a block and a half.

BALTIMORE, MD., FEB. 19, 1912
Time to Act.

Barely three months and a half
remain before the present seniors
will be graduated. But this is
plenty of time.for plans to be made
for a more adequate commence- •
ment, with a class day, or night, a
baccalaureate sermon, a banquet, a
trip down the bay, the presentation
of a play, or any activity which
would help keep memorable the last
week which many of us will spend
at the Johns Hopkins University.
Tiii Xi.:\vs-LETTER believes that
it is. a crying shame that more
sentiment is not attached by the
students to the graduation exercises, but when any complaint is
made, that perennial sins-of-omission excuse is heard: "Wait until
We get to Homewood." We have
been waiting though for several
years,- and we will have to wait
Several more. • The time to act is
now.
And SO THE NMS-LETTER respectfully suggests to President
Lee, of the senior class, that he appoint at once a committee to make
plans for some student celebrations
.during commencement week. We
believe that there is a widespread
sentiment favoring this, and if a
committee made some good sugkestions, the favorable sentiment
would speedily crystallize into support.

The third speaker was Mr. Hanrahan, of Loyola, whose penchant

journeyman's speech and charmed
the whole audience with the remarkably soothing qualities of his
voice.
The fourth place fell to the representative of St. John's, Mr. Edgar
T. Fell. Mr. Fell, who is what the
older novelists would have called a
"very pretty boy," is apparently a
new hand at the game, and was
seriously handicapped by his inexperience. He has not yet learned
how to make the best use of his
voice, and his boyish enthusiasm
led him into many high places
which he would otherwise probably
have avoided.
The last speaker, Mr. Wendell
DeWitt Allen, of Washington College, deserves more than a modicum
of credit for having stirred a tired
and sleepy audience to attention and
interest. His style of speaking, although altogether too passionate,
too unrestrained, too prone to climax, was at least rather effective,
and reminded one not a little of the
style of Mr. Howe, of Michigan,
who won first prize last year in the
Interstate Contest.

STRAYER'S

(Continued from Page I)

Dear Sir—My room-mate, Bessie
B., has got a terrible grouch on me.
I am sitting in the hall writing to
tell you about it all. This Wednesday, as your calendar will say, is,
. of course, St. Valentine's Day. Bessie B. is a. popular girl(quite mixed
UP in the social swirl) goes to
• all .the. Hopkins dances, slides and
turns the queerest prances.
It's no wonder then, you see, Bessie's got the grouch on me, for I've
upset her silly notions that she's
the height of men's devotions. A
.box of candy had come for Bessie,
it looked quite fine and somewhat
dressy. Gold string. held the paper,*
too—paper red and white and blue!
Bessie in her condescending way:
"Sallie, take the paper off, I say !"
I was really nothing loth, I took the
Paper and the lid off both. Inside
was a graven card—"Your valentine, T. William Bard." It would
have been all right to have stopped
there, but I'm not the kind to stop
anywhere I pressed down on something hard—it was the candvstore
man's card. Now, Editor, I'll bet
-voull roar—that card read:"Kirby's
'Five and Ten Cent Store!"
I had to flee to save rny head.
Bessie's gone weeping to bed. But
m v head's fiery and my temper, too.

The authorities request the punctual attendance of all students, members of the faculty and trustees.
The following order will be preserved:
The trustees, the faculty, and the
official guests are invited to assemble
at 10.30 o'clock in Levering Hall,
corner of Eutaw street and Druid
Hill avenue.
The alumni are invited to assemble at 10.30 in the second story
of McCoy Hall (north side).
The students are requested to
meet at 10.20 in the places designated below, and will proceed, under
the direction of their marshals, to
the seats reserved for them:
Graduate students in the arts and
sciences, in Room io, McCoy Hall.
Students of medicine, in Room
12, McCoy Hall.
Undergraduate students, in Room
McCoy Hall.
The procession will enter the assembly room at 10.45.
A part of the assembly room will
be reserved until 10.45 for the families of the trustees and faculty, who
will be admitted by special cards.
After the procession has entered,
the remaining seats will be open to
the public without tickets.

The man who said there was
nothing new under the sun evidently started to look around for antique
furniture.

location of the dormitories has been
asked for for a baseball field, and
if the request is granted, the dormitories will have to be shifted. These
problems were put up to the new
Advisory Board, and they came together with President Remsen and
Mr. R. Brent Keyser last Thursday
night to confer. It is probable that
a complete shift will be made in the
original plans. This will no doubt
take some time and cause a delay
in actual building.
It is expected that the University
will be formally told of the changes
at the commemoration day exercises
next Thursday. It has been the
custom for the last few years to report the progress on the Homewood
plans on this occasion, and judging
from the precedent, some part of
the program will be devoted to the
Homewood development. Nd actual work has been done on the tract
in the past year, except the erection of some new buildings in the
botanical gardens, and some grading. Between $6o,000 and $7o,00o
has been spent so far, excluding the
salaries of the workmen.
Very few people realize the size
of the Wyman tract on which the
new University is to stand. Professor Mathews, of the geological
department, who is one of the most
enthusiastic workers on the Homewood Board, has compared the size
of the Homewood grounds with the
size of the business section of the
city. He placed a map of the tract
on a map of the city, both of which
were on the same scale, placing the
southernmost point of the tract
on 'Baltimore and Liberty streets.
Charles street will fall on Charles
street. With the maps so placed,
the north end of Homewood will
fall On the Richmond Market Armory. The tract extends in breadth
from Charles street to about as far
as Eutaw. The library to be built
according to the new plans could
hardly be placed on the present site
of the University. The new laboratories will cover about three blocks.
The dormitories will occupy about
a block and a half.
